docs.lead_paragraph: Motorcycle deaths jumped by more than a third from 1998 to 2000, with most of the increase involving middle-aged riders on big bikes, according to a new study of data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The study, published in this month's Annals of Emergency Medicine, showed that while riders over 40 still accounted for a minority of motorcycle deaths, they were the only group whose death rate increased over the last decade. In 1990, the average age of a rider killed in a crash was 29 and the average engine size was 769 cubic centimeters; in 1999, the average age had risen to 36.5 and the average engine to 922 cubic centimeters.
docs.abstract: Study of data from National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, published in Annals of Emergency Medicine, finds that motorcycle deaths increased by more than third from 1998 to 2000, with most of increase involving middle-aged riders on big bikes; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Everybody knows that 14-year-olds make critical judgments about the value of their parents' advice, but 14-month-olds? A new study involving babies, a blanket and a woman turning a lamp on and off with her forehead suggests that they do. The study, published last week in the journal Nature, followed up an experiment in which babies watched a woman switch on a light box by bumping it with her head instead of her hands. About two-thirds of them used the same method when given a chance.
docs.abstract: Researchers in Budapest and Munich, in study published in journal Nature, describe experiment in which babies watched woman, sometimes holding blanket around herself pretending to be cold, turn lamp on and off with her forehead; conclude that babies evaluate rationality of means in relation to goal; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 77-year-old woman from Plainview, N.Y., wrote that after a recent bone density test, she was told she had osteopenia. Although she is very active, takes 1,500 milligrams of calcium and 400 international units of vitamin D every day and uses a vaginal estrogen cream, her internist and gynecologist recommend that she take medication to rebuild lost bone and prevent further loss.

headline.main: Strong Bones, With and Without Drugs

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column describes differences between osteopenia and osteoporosis and ways both can be controlled and treated; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A review of research into over-the-counter cough medicines published in The British Medical Journal found little evidence that they make much of a difference. The review, conducted by researchers from the University of Bristol, looked at 15 studies involving 2,166 patients that compared the effect of the medicines with a placebo syrup. In nine of the studies, including the only two that looked solely at antihistamines, the cough medicines appeared to be no more helpful than the plain syrup.

headline.main: Cough Syrup Is Usually No Sure Cure

docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Bristol, in review published in British Medical Journal, concludes over-the-counter cough medicines have little therapeutic value (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe the problem in the modern diet isn't the amount of meat we eat, but the diet of the animals whose meat we're eating, according to two studies based on research comparing current diets with those of Paleolithic man. Wild animals not only have less total fat than livestock fed on grain, but more of their fat is of a kind (omega-3) thought to be good for cardiac health, and less of a kind (omega-6) that promotes heart disease, said the studies, published in the March issue of The European Journal of Clinical Nutrition. Many of the same benefits were found in grass-fed livestock, also known as free range.

headline.main: But What Did the Cow Have for Lunch?

docs.abstract: Two studies comparing current diets with those of Paleolithic man, published in March issue of European Journal of Clinical Nutrition, conclude that problem with modern diet may not be the amount of meat we eat, but rather the diet of that livestock; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The movie ''John Q.'' stars Denzel Washington as John Q. Archibald, a father so desperate to obtain a heart transplant for his son that when his H.M.O. refuses to pay for the operation he takes over an emergency room at gunpoint. This hospital cum hostage drama opened nationwide last week amid some brickbats from reviewers, although in this case it was not just movie critics who weighed in. Health policy analysts, transplant coordinators and managed care advocates had plenty to say about ''John Q.,'' even before it opened. Does the story at the heart of the film square with real life?

headline.main: More Drama Added to Politics of Transplants

docs.abstract: Health policy analysts, organ transplant coordinators, managed care advocates and American Assn of Health Plans voice opposition to new movie, John Q, about father who takes over hospital emergency room at gunpoint when HMO refuses to pay for son's heart transplant; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is always interesting to talk to smokers about their habits. Young ones say they will quit soon (most of them won't); older ones, resigned to being hooked, come up with a variety of rationales. One woman told me she did not care if she died 10 years earlier -- the important thing was enjoying her life, and that meant smoking. What she seemed to believe was that at some point she would have a peaceful, easy death, but that if she kept smoking, it would simply come a decade sooner. No big deal.

headline.main: Pulling Back The Curtain Of Smoke

docs.abstract: Hubert B Herring article describes slow, excruciating death from emphysema and eventual asphyxiation of his 59-year-old father-in-law, who was heavy smoker (Cases column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Up to 20 million Americans may be in an early stage of chronic kidney disease and not know it, and another 20 million face an above average risk of developing it, the National Kidney Foundation said in announcing guidelines that should sharply increase screening for the condition. Dr. Andrew S. Levey of the Tufts University School of Medicine, the head of the panel that developed the guidelines, said the approach was driven by new evidence both of the extent of the problem and of the possibility of effective treatment.

headline.main: Catching Kidney Disease in Early Stages

docs.abstract: National Kidney Foundation announces guidelines that should sharply increase screening for chronic kidney disease; notes up to 20 million may have early stage of disease and another 20 million face above average risk (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''ER: Enter at Your Own Risk,'' by Dr. Joel Cohen, New Horizon Press, $14.95. ''Baby ER,'' by Edward Humes, Simon & Schuster, $25. A medical emergency is unquestionably a harrowing experience for the patient, and it is equally so for the physician who is suddenly called upon to give care. Judgment must be exercised to ensure that the case is indeed an emergency, the right procedures and instruments must be selected, and, above all, the physician must show unflagging confidence in handling a bewildering variety of illnesses and trauma.

headline.main: Divergent Views of Surviving in the E.R. Maze

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews books ER: Enter at Your Own Risk by Dr Joel Cohen and Baby ER by Edward Humes; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Marion Nestle brought out her newest toy, a bright red and yellow McDonald's Deluxe Mealtime Set. She hadn't even opened it, but you could see all 37 molded plastic pieces through the cellophane box top. There were toy burgers and fries, toy hash browns and McNuggets, toy chocolate chip cookies, even toy packets of ketchup and sweet and sour sauce. ''This whole box was only $9!'' she exclaimed, as if proud to have spotted a bargain. ''Isn't it fun? It's adorable!'' But she quickly dropped the sarcasm and got to the point: ''It's advertising, and I paid for it. If it was cigarettes, people would be appalled.''

headline.main: An 'Eat More' Message For a Fattened America

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Marion Nestle, head of New York University's nutrition and food studies department, who comments on her new book, Food Politics, and her belief, based on reams of evidence, that food industry engages in politics to influence American diet; photo (M)
